channel.title: BBC News - Africa

item.title: Ethiopia: Fact-checking misleading images about hunger in Amhara
item.description: Food shortages are worsening in Ethiopia but some images online are not what they claim to be.

item.title: The link between climate change, seaweed and ice cream
item.description: Seaweed production has been affected by warming seas – this is how farmers are adapting.

item.title: Johannesburg mayor Jolidee Matongo killed in car crash
item.description: South Africa's President Ramaphosa pays tribute to Jolidee Matongo, who died at the age of 46.

item.title: Germaine Acogny: 'The mother of contemporary African dance'
item.description: Germaine Acogny has recently been awarded the prestigious Golden Lion award at the Venice Biennale Dance festival. But what impact has she had on African contemporary dance?

item.title: Sexual abuse scandal overshadows start of Women's Afrobasket finals
item.description: Africa's women's basketballers start the continental championships on Saturday under the shadow of a major sexual abuse scandal.

item.title: Abdelaziz Bouteflika: Former Algerian president dies aged 84
item.description: Bouteflika led Algeria for 20 years, but his bid for a fifth term led to huge protests in 2019.

item.title: Kenya's CBC education reform: How scarecrows are terrifying parents
item.description: A new school curriculum means challenging tasks end up being performed by parents not their children.

item.title: Turkana: The front line of climate change
item.description: There are few places in the world where the consequences of a changing climate are as plain to see as in northern Kenya.

item.title: Abdelaziz Bouteflika, Algeria's longest-serving president dies
item.description: The former president, whose decades-long rule sparked massive protests, has died aged 84.

item.title: Kenyan influencers paid to take 'guerrilla warfare’ online
item.description: Shadowy financiers are closing down a once democratic space on Twitter for political debate in Kenya.

item.title: Nigeria's kidnap crisis: Letters replace phones
item.description: The latest tactic to tackle kidnapping gangs is to cut off mobiles and the internet.

item.title: Ethiopia: The country where a year lasts 13 months
item.description: Five things you may not know about Ethiopia's unique calendar and cultural heritage.

item.title: The Kenyans who are helping the world to cheat
item.description: Some Kenyans try to escape poverty by helping foreign students to fake their academic work.

item.title: Guinea coup: Are military takeovers on the rise in Africa?
item.description: Despite a series of coups in Africa over the past few months, the longer trend down is downward.

item.title: The South African farm turning flies into food for pets - and maybe people
item.description: A South African company is aiming to take advantage of a new interest in protein-rich insects.

item.title: Kenyan blogger: 'I thought I may never make it out of Qatar'
item.description: A Kenyan blogger who wrote about working conditions in Qatar was thrown into solitary confinement, given a huge fine and deported.

item.title: On the trail of fake medicine smugglers in Benin
item.description: Since the beginning of the pandemic, there’s been an increase in counterfeit drugs around the world.

item.title: What's gone wrong with the 'War on Terror' in Africa?
item.description: Twenty years after the US 'War on Terror' began, Islamist movements have spread across Africa.

item.title: Life at 50C: The toxic gas flares fuelling Nigeria's climate change
item.description: Joy and her family are among 2m Nigerians living within 4km of a gas flare in Nigeria's oil-rich south.

item.title: Kenya's Chief Justice Martha Koome: Tackling Kenya's corruption
item.description: Kenya’s Chief Justice Martha Koome says she is focusing on building a judiciary that Kenyans can have confidence in.

item.title: Why people in Eswatini are protesting
item.description: Eswatini is Africa’s last absolute monarchy, which means the king controls everything.

item.title: The Gambia: Why is Yahya Jammeh's possible return causing such a stir?
item.description: The Gambia’s notorious and exiled former president could be seen back in the country and possibly on the political scene.
